page.title: 02Woodlands of Kent - History
page.content: The Weald of Kent is part of the "Forest of Andresweald". These woods were made up of oak trees. There were clearings in the wood called dens. This is why most of the villages and towns nearby have the letters den or dene at the end of their names (eg. Tenterden, Halden or Bethersden). The owners kept their pigs in these dens, because in the Autumn the acorns fall and pigs love acorns. Oak trees were used for building houses and furniture because it is very strong. Oak trees were good for hollowing out to make boats. This was done at a little town, called Smallhythe, just outside Tenterden. The boats would sail down the little river to the coast. Oak was used for firewood. Fires were used for iron-smelting and warmth.
